bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry R. Viets, February 18, 1941

div1.p: Hench describes four papers dealing with the historical research on yellow fever. He prefers to have all four published as a small monograph.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry R. Viets, February 18, 1941
div1.opener:
leave on desk.
February 18, 1941
Dr. Henry R. Viets
Bulletin of the Medical Library Association
8 The Fenway
Boston, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Viets:
div1.p:
I appreciate very much your offer to read my manuscripts
regarding my historical researches on yellow fever. I haven't decided
what to do with them. I have four papers which are or will be available.
One pertains to the newer data on Dr. Lazear, the second is the story
of Mr. Kissinger, and the third is the story of Mr. Moran. These two
men were the first two to volunteer to Dr. Reed for experimental yellow
fever. The fourth is the story of the relocation of Camp Lazear, with
new historical documentation. They are all fairly short articles.

I I have had some correspondence with others as to where they
should be published and I realize that you cannot commit yourself before
seeing them, but I wondered whether you would be inclined to publish
all four, or do you think your readers would be fed up with one article?
I should like to have all four printed, and then perhaps get a small
number of reprints to bind as a small monograph.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
